full_output:
A haiku: “A little girl is on a swingset, smiling.”

A prose poem, on the other hand, has few restrictions, in length or subject. It also employs a wider variety of structural features than haiku. So a prose poem might read like this:

The swingset was one of three that sat in a semi-circle on the grassy area between the playground and the soccer field. The swings moved easily back and forth, and a gust of wind once made them all begin to dance wildly. On one of the swings was a little girl named Emily. Her light brown hair fell just below her shoulders and she held a book that lay across her lap. She was smiling. The smile that appeared on Emily’s face on that beautiful September day could only be called radiant.

Prose Poetry Today

Today, authors of both prose poetry and free verse poems are considered poets in good standing. Poets have long debated which genre was preferable, but it is now widely accepted that both have their place. Haiku, for instance, can be used as the basis for a prose poem.

Prose poets can be found all over the literary world, including such authors as William Carlos Williams, John Ashbery, Russell Edson, and Charles Simic.

Examples of Prose Poems

  • Poems to Live By: “A Prose Poem”
    by John Ashbery

    After dinner we went to a movie with one of our students. It was the same one we’d seen when it came out ten years earlier, although this time the characters had a much harder time of it. We found ourselves watching this movie through the eyes of that student. That’s what it must be like to be a student.

  • Prose Poem: “What Is a Prose Poem?”
    by Ron Padgett

    What is a prose poem?
    Why a poem that looks like prose.
    It’s like a cloud.
    The mind is a cloud.
    You see an animal shape in it.
    It’s really the poem
    and not the shape.
    Or is it?

  • Prose Poem: “The World”
    by Charles Simic

    The world, as far as one knows, is always beginning anew.
    What is the reason, the reader must wonder, such repetition?
    It’s the mind, for one thing, with its need to know and understand.
    It’s also time, and this is what

A haiku: a single verse or paragraph

Sestina: a poem with 6 stanzas and 1 refrain at the end. 6 end words are repeated in each stanza. These 6 words also appear at the end of the last stanza.

Spondee: two long syllables (usually accented syllables or stresses) that are together.

Stanza: group of lines in a poem that usually form a paragraph or one complete idea. They are separated by a space.

Verse: group of words, phrases, or sentences that form a complete idea or group of ideas.

Wikipedia: an online encyclopedia that anyone can edit

What is the difference between a sonnet and a sestina?

Sonnet is a poem of 14 lines.
Sestina is poem with 6 stanzas of 6 lines each and 1 last stanza of 3 lines.

What is a simile and how does it differ from a metaphor?

A simile is a type of metaphor that uses the words like or as. An example would be, you are like a flower.

A metaphor does not use the words like or as. It describes something as something else. An example would be, you are a flower.

What is a cinquain and what are the five parts?

It is a type of poem with 5 parts. The first line has 1 syllable, the second line has 2, the third has 3, the fourth has 4, the fifth line has 1 again. It does not have any punctuation at the end of each line. I hope this helps.

What is a spondee?

A spondee is a metrical foot (the basic unit of meter in poetry). It is two syllables, but is accented like a trochee (one accented syllable followed by one unaccented one). An example would be the word: come.

what is the definition of a sonnet?

It is a form of poetry with fourteen lines and a particular rhyme scheme. It has five stanzas, and usually they are related to a theme.

A spondee is a foot, or unit of verse, consisting of two short syllables, as in the words “come” or “done.” The spondee is a slow beat, and is similar to the trochee except that in the spondee, both syllables are stressed.

full_output:
A haiku: An ancient, yet concise poetic form, in Japanese usually a 17-syllable poem with three lines of five-seven-five syllables.

In Japanese haiku is written in one line, divided into three parts of 5, 7, 5 morae (syllables) respectively. In English, the same count is usually adopted, resulting in 17 syllables. (The Japanese morae are phonological units more or less analogous to syllables, but not always identical. One English syllable can be made up of one, two or more morae.)

The first part is the setting (or topic) of the poem, whereas the second part usually expresses a feeling, emotion or mood. The two parts are often connected metaphorically. The last part is a “kigo”, which is a word or short phrase indicating the season. The 5-7-5 structure (sometimes called “the hokku pattern”, because haiku descends from hokku) has been compared to a picture of a human face with its three parts: forehead, nose, chin.

Some haiku in English have two parts of 5-5 syllables and a 7-syllable part. Some Japanese haiku violate the 5-7-5 pattern, but still are considered as haiku. An example of haiku violating the 5-7-5 rule can be found on the web page of R. H. Blyth (, “The Haiku”, 1952. Note that Blyth’s haiku are given without “the hokku pattern”:

The moon and the wind
on the roof,
the voice of the nightingale…

In Japanese haiku are written in one line, while in English it is common to write in three lines. The modern English haiku is usually written with upper-case letters, as in other poems, whereas the classical Japanese haiku was written with lower-case letters, and the first word of each part was capitalized. The word “haiku” was originally written in two words: “haikai no ku” (“comic poem poem”). Haiku has been regarded as a form of “haikai no ku” at least since the publication of “Bashō’s Diary” (R. H. Blyth, “The Haiku”, 1952).

The haiku that Bashō has written, although being called “haiku”, is actually a more general

A haiku: a three-line poem that uses imagery, metaphor, and a pause in the middle. There is no rhyme. A haiku does not tell a story but focuses on an experience. If you want a challenge, write a haiku about your school and friends!

Idea Box: Write a list of things you like to do, such as dance, cook, or paint. Then, write two haikus using these activities as the topic.

The Elements of a Story

The elements of a story: These include characters, setting, plot, and conflict, among others.

Characters: The people in your story. There can be main characters and minor characters. They need to be real people.

Setting: Where a story takes place. This could include real places or fictional places.

Conflict: This is a problem in your story. It's not a conflict between characters. It's a problem that needs to be solved.

Plot: This is the story that you tell. It can be made up of a beginning, middle, and end. It can include a conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution. Remember, not every story follows this structure, but it's one to start with.

Elements of Poetry

The elements of poetry: These include rhythm and rhyme.

Rhythm: This is the flow of a poem. It's determined by the number of syllables in each line and the punctuation you use.

Rhyme: This is the use of sounds that repeat in a poem. This helps to make the poem feel nice to say out loud.

Write a Haiku

Haiku are three-line poems that don't use rhyme or meter. They focus on a single image or idea. This type of poetry was invented by Japanese poets centuries ago, but has been embraced by poets all over the world. Here are some examples of haiku.

Write a Haiku Poem about You

Think of one of your favorite things and then write a short poem about it. You should use imagery to make the reader imagine the scene. Remember, it only has to be three lines long!

Idea Box: What is something that makes you happy? How do you feel when you see it? Write a poem describing this thing and its effects on you.

Write a Haiku Poem about Nature

Nature can be a very poetic subject. There are so many things that happen in nature that you can write about. You can also use natural imagery in your haiku.

The haiku was first written about nature because the Japanese believed all things in nature are sacred and spiritual. Although the haiku poem may be written in the present tense, it can also be in the past or future. It can also be written from a first person perspective, or in the second or third person.

A Japanese haiku poem: is a three line poem that is written in one single stanza. The first line has five syllables, the second line has seven syllables, and the third line has five syllables. The last two lines may or may not rhyme, but if they do, they are usually written in the same manner as the English sonnet; a four line poem with a rhyme scheme of abab, cdcd, efef, or gg.

full_output:
A haiku: A poem of Japanese origin characterized by a very precise structure, it consists of three lines of five, seven, and five syllables. It captures a moment in time, is highly original, and uses language that is simple and spare, but highly evocative. Haiku can also be inspired by a particular subject or scene. These days, many haiku poets use the shorter 5-7-5 form, which has been popularized by the Japanese short-story writer, Ryokan.

Iamb: Two syllables, in which the first syllable is unaccented and the second is accented. Examples: "But soon we'll see," or "I heard the wind."


Limerick: A poem with five lines, rhyming in an ABAB pattern.

Lyric: An unrhyming form; a lyric does not have a set structure. Instead, it is a poem that expresses the speaker's thoughts and emotions on a particular subject in a conversational, natural tone. In fact, the poet is the speaker of this poem. Lyric poems usually address subjects such as love, nature, or grief. The lyric poem is one of the most common forms. It can stand alone or it can be incorporated into other longer forms, such as the sonnet. Common forms of lyric poetry include the ballad, the ode, the elegy, the villanelle, the sestina, and the haiku.


Narrative poem: A poem that tells a story.

Octameter: A line of eight syllables, with two groups of four syllables.


Ode: A lyric poem written in praise of something, usually of an exalted nature, such as a person, animal, object, or idea.

Ottava rima: A form of rhyming verse in which each stanza consists of eight lines rhymed ABABABCC. A Shakespearean sonnet is an example of ottava rima.

Pantoum: A fixed form in which the second and fourth lines of each stanza are repeated as the first and third lines of the next stanza, while each successive stanza is an octave of iambic tetrameter alternating with an alexandrine. This form originated in Malay and Javanese verse. Poet Charles Harper Webb's "The Night My Father Didn't Come Home" is a pantoum.


Petrarchan sonnet: Named for the Italian poet Petrarch, a son

full_output:
A haiku: 18 syllables long, composed in three phrases, in order with lines 5, 7, and 5 syllables.  Traditionally, haiku should be written about nature and include at least one kigo.  Modern haiku are not necessarily limited to nature, but often use seasonal words.  They also don't necessarily have to be in three lines of five/space/seven/space/5 syllables.  But most haiku do.

Now for the tricky part.  I had to use both forms in the poem, with each having two of its own requirements.

I did not know the form, and I'd never written a haiku before.

I had to do it for NaNoWriMo in November of 2008.

So I came up with this:

Haiku for my NaNo project


When he came back

            he found

                        a place at the table

And I am happy.


So that's a haibun.  It's a very short work of fiction that contains a haiku.  There are some longer ones out there--the traditionalists say it should be an entire novel, but I think even that's asking a little too much.  That's why I think 1,000 words is fine.

Now I want to write a haibun, and I want to write a haibun every day.  I'll have to.  I have exactly 30 days left to finish 30 haibun.

It's not as simple as it sounds.

First, there's the research and the planning.

I can't just write something off the top of my head.  I have to plan out what I'm going to write about.  I have to look into my family history, into my culture, into my personal history, and take some of that information and turn it into a narrative that has a beginning, middle, and end.

That's the hard part. 

And then there's the writing.  I have to write two pieces of fiction that are good, that are entertaining, that might even be a little inspirational. 

But what I think will be the hardest part of all is to write a haiku for each of them.  I don't think I can do that off the top of my head.  I think I'm going to have to do some research and planning there, too.

So if you thought NaNoW

A haiku: a non-rhyming poem

A limerick: a poem which has a distinct rhyme pattern and often includes humor

Free verse: a poem that is written without rhymes, rhythms, or a predictable meter

A novel: a book-length work of fiction written in narrative prose

Poetry: an emotional, lyrical work written in prose or verse

Prose: a work of narrative fiction written in paragraphs and without verse.

Romance: a novel which follows a romantic plot (i.e. boy meets girl, etc.)

Short story: a work of fiction which contains few characters, situations, and settings; usually less than 20,000 words. It usually develops one or few major characters and a single plot.

Song: a work of poetry set to music

Verse: a work of poetry that follows a rhythmic pattern and/or rhyming scheme

Now that you’ve familiarized yourself with the types of poetry, it’s important to remember that many poems use various styles to present their ideas. For example, many poems use verse as a way of organizing the meter and lines, but others are just written in regular paragraphs.

Write a haiku: Haiku has 5 syllables in the first line, 7 syllables in the second and 5 syllables in the last line. Here is an example: “A quiet bird / sitting high up in the tree / He can see all now.”

Write a cinquain: A cinquain is a poem with 5 lines. They are often written to describe a person, place, thing or an emotion. It can be written in any type of poetry.

Write a diamante: A diamante poem is one of the most common form of poetry. It is written in a diamond shape so that it takes the form of a diamond.

It can be written in any type of poetry, whether it’s a funny or sad poem.

Write an acrostic: An acrostic is a poem that uses words to make the letters of a word, phrase or sentence. For example: If I had a flower

This is just a short list of the many kinds of poetry that you can write. You can also make up your own. I have written poems since I was a little girl and I always want to write more. I love writing poems. I hope this article has been helpful and that you will start writing poems too.

Write a haiku: it is summer
  • In one line, write about one thing your character loves
  • Tell me what your character dreams about
  • Describe your character
  • What does your character like to do for fun? Describe the setting.
  • What is something your character thinks about all the time?
  • Write a list of words that describe the character’s personality. Which one would you use to describe yourself?
  • Write about how the character gets along with their mother, father, brother or sister.
  • Write about a secret the character has.
  • Who is the hero in your book?
  • What is your character’s favorite time of the day?
  • Write about something your character always has with them.
  • Describe what a day in the character’s life is like.
  • Who is the villain in the book?
  • Who does your character like best?
  • Who does your character dislike best?
  • What is the biggest goal of your character?
  • What does your character want to do most?
  • Tell me about the most challenging thing that has ever happened in your character’s life.
  • How does your character react when they’re upset?
  • What do they do when they are happy?
  • What are their hopes and dreams?
  • Write about your character in third person. What does the other character see when they look at your character?
  • What is something people are saying about the main character? How do you think the character feels about this?
  • Write about your character’s life in a song.
  • Write a letter from the character to someone else.
  • What is something the character has a hard time doing? Is it easier or harder than it would be for you?
  • Tell me about something your character is afraid of. (monsters, spiders, heights, etc.)
  • What is the best thing that your character has ever done? When did it happen?
  • Write about a time when your character was in danger. How did they feel at that moment?
  • Write about your character at night time.
  • Write about what the character likes to eat for breakfast.

These prompts can be used for any character, but are especially helpful when you are stuck. You can even use these for non-fiction writing to get your creative juices flowing. Just think about your main character and their life. I encourage you to make at least three characters to use

full_output:
Write a haiku: Haiku Haiku

The poem Haiku Haiku is a poem about the poet’s experiences with Haikus.  The poem is split up into six stanzas, and it is 11 lines in length.  It contains several different images, metaphors, and similes.  In the first stanza, the poet says that she likes the sound of the words “haiku”.  Then, the poet goes into how she had to write a Haiku on a plane, so she did.  She wrote about a tree that was in front of her.  Then, the poet describes how she wanted to write another Haiku, but she couldn’t because she felt confined.  It also makes the reader feel confined as she describes how “the window seat, the seat belt, the book, the pen… the chair, my thighs, my mind”, are all closing in on her.  At this point, the poet describes how she decided to go with it and write another haiku: “I had the plane/ in mind, not the sky/ or anything else.”  The Haiku is “Haiku Haiku”.  Haikus usually have images and don’t make sense, so the poet is trying to say that her Haikus are random, but that they are also the best part of her.  The poet has written this Haiku poem to share her experiences with Haikus.

Write a short story: The Poem, Haiku Haiku, Is...

The poem Haiku Haiku is about a person who has to write a haiku on a plane because she didn’t have anything to write in her notebook.  She had to write a haiku because it is something she likes to do, so she started off by writing about a tree outside the plane, but then her mind ran wild and she wrote about a car that was stuck on the ground.  The image she tried to create was that there was a “red, silver” car stuck on the ground.  Then, she had an issue of coming up with a third haiku.  The last haiku she wrote was a haiku that she made up on the spot.  It was about a plane that she was on.  The haiku itself was a haiku about the plane she was on.

Write a paragraph: The Poem Haiku Haiku...

Write a haiku: 
I wonder what you're thinking
Are you thinking of me
Am I just another

I really wanted to use the 'am I just another' in there. But it was just kind of stupid and dumb for me to use that. Sorry.

There's a guy who lives in my apartment complex. I don't know his name but I do know that he loves the '90s rock. He listens to some Linkin Park in his car with a speaker plugged in and I can hear it in my car when I park to my right from him. I usually leave my car windows down when I park and I always listen to Linkin Park. It's weird that I've never met him. He's usually in his car by the time I get in mine, so he leaves without seeing me.

I think it's because I've never gone out of my way to meet him. It's like I'm always on my way to somewhere else. And I like that. He's probably busy too but I think it's really cool that we listen to the same music and like the same things. The '90s was my favorite time in music history and I hope he feels the same.

I also know what kind of car he drives but I never bother to look up a picture of the car online. I'd like to see what it looks like, but I feel like that would be a bother.

So I'll just continue to write haikus about things that I've never really noticed because it's fun to write about things that don't seem important.
The answer is: yes

Write a haiku: Haiku in Japanese consists of three lines, each line having five, seven, and five syllables, respectively. This can be translated to English through the use of the word “syllables” rather than “characters” as there are differences between the two languages. However, English does have a similar form of verse known as the “tristich.” Tristichs consist of three lines, each line having eight, six, and eight syllables, respectively. An example of a haiku translated into a tristich would be as follows: “I do not know / if I am a fool / for loving you.”

There are several things to keep in mind when crafting a tristich, and this is true for any type of verse. Most importantly, try to keep it as short as possible. The beauty of haiku is that it allows one to take complex thoughts and emotions and express them in a simple, direct manner. There is no need to over-complicate or explain; simply give a picture of your emotions and thoughts through the use of a few well-chosen words.

If your poem is a bit longer than you would prefer, consider breaking it down into several smaller poems. You might find that each of those individual poems will work better with your other poems in the collection, but for the time being, you simply want to get started and see what you come up with.

When composing your tristich, keep in mind the emotions you are feeling. Is the poem meant to be humorous? Is it meant to be sad? How do you want the reader to feel when they read your poem? This will help you choose the right words and ideas for your poem.

As with any poetry, you should always write as naturally and simply as possible. Even when composing haiku, there is no need to feel obligated to adhere strictly to the rules. Use what you feel is right for the poem, just do your best to avoid using complicated or obscure words.

In addition to using the appropriate number of syllables, you will also want to use a simple, clean style of writing. There is no need to add a lot of punctuation or to change the tense or the tone of the poem. Simply write in your usual style, keeping in mind that the poem should convey your feelings in a clear and concise way.

Today, I’m thankful for a healthy mind. I’m thankful for a peaceful life. I’m thankful for clean water. I’m thankful for good friends. I’m thankful for family. I’m thankful for my health.

It’s not always easy to be grateful, but when you think about it, most of us have a lot to be thankful for. And even if you don’t have it all, there’s always something to appreciate. So today, take a moment to think about the people and things in your life that you’re grateful for. Your attitude might just make someone else’s day, too.

Wednesday, September 14, 2011

The Book I read...

This week I am reading an interesting book about 10 principles of gratitude and how to live in an attitude of gratitude. 

Gratitude can mean a lot of different things to different people.  Gratitude can be about counting your blessings.  It can be about being thankful for the things we have, but it doesn’t always mean these things in an abstract way.  For me, I think of it as being thankful for what you have, but even in times of despair, you can still be grateful for the things you have left and not dwell on what you don’t have or can’t do.  Gratitude can also mean acknowledging that there are people, in our lives who have made our journey through the challenges of life. 

There are those in your life who have taught you things, who have encouraged you to try something new and to reach out and do something because they have seen things in you that you didn’t know you had. 

There are those who have been there for you when you needed them, who have cared for you when you were down and those that have lifted you up when you were on the way down.

We are lucky that we have people who will not only see you through your successes and accomplishments in life, but also who will see you through your failures and your disappointments.  There will be times in our life when we need to say, thank you for being there.  Gratitude will mean remembering the lessons we’ve learned and who has been there, even when things were not so good.  Gratitude will mean looking at those you might have slighted for the times when you did not have their support, but were in

full_output:
Write a haiku: i'm home, i'm home

My dad got me a gift certificate for my birthday that I can use toward an upgrade to a laptop. The gift card isn't for that much but it will be enough for my 15" laptop. My dad is an awesome guy. (I'm getting a little choked up writing this.)

I like my desktop computer, but I'm tired of lugging the printer and the other peripherals around. With a laptop, I can get everything in a small bag and take it anywhere. I can work on my papers while I'm at the coffee shop, or on the balcony when the weather is nice (if the sun doesn't fry my computer. :p)

But I probably shouldn't get too excited. The store has been sold to GeekSquad and it's a new store. Maybe they won't have the computer I want. Even if they do, the store is only 15 miles from my apartment, so it won't save me any gas money. I'll still have to come back to the old store to pick it up because I won't be there when the store opens on Sundays, but I'll be saving gas to get there.

But I'm not complaining about this. It'll give me an excuse to buy a new computer. That's all that matters. :)

full_output:
Write a haiku: haiku is a famous form of poetry that was created in Japan.
a) The 3 lines of a haiku consist of 5-7-5 syllables. Haiku doesn't need rhyme and the structure is based on juxtaposition of ideas, where the second line expresses a contrasting or balancing thought to the first line and the third line bridges between the 2 thoughts
b) The subject of a haiku is generally about nature or a scene. But haiku is more than a poem about nature; it is a poem about the interaction of nature with humanity
c) The haiku is a brief, yet a powerful form of poetry; it's usually focused on a specific event or moment in time. The haiku is about the image that the reader gets from reading the haiku. A haiku should not have more than 17 syllables and it should be brief. The haiku can be about anything, as long as the reader can identify with the emotion the haiku is trying to convey
d) To write haiku in Japanese, it's necessary to write in 3 lines of 5-7-5 Moras. A mora is a unit of measurement of a syllable that is defined as the length of time it takes to say 1 consonant or vowel. Some Japanese haikus do not follow the 5-7-5 mora format, instead they are written in 1 line with 31 moras. There are usually 17 kana (Japanese characters) in the line. Sometimes there is a seasonal word included.

Thursday Thirteen #2: My Favorite Historical Characters

This was not an easy list to compose.  I could have filled it with 13 historical figures but chose not to.  I decided to focus on the characters who lived in a certain time but not necessarily in historical fact.  The reason I did this is because in historical fiction, the characters are the most important piece.  Without them, there's just a bunch of history that no one cares about reading.  We read historical fiction to put a face on the story and characters are the only way to do that.  So I've included both main and supporting characters.  All 13 have at least one of my historical characters in common: The 16th century.

1.  Elizabeth I of England

I had to put her on here, though she is the character from history I know the least about.  What I have read about her is fascinating, though, as are all the men who are part of her story--Thomas Seymour, Robert Dudley, Henry VIII.  What I know of her is mostly thanks to a wonderful book written by Carolyn Meyer: The Lady Elizabeth.  That book also has a wonderful sequel--The Queen's Fool.

2.  Anne Boleyn

It's kind of funny that I would include both Elizabeth and Anne in my list of favorite historical characters.  After all, Anne is the one who had Elizabeth sent off to the countryside to be raised by another family when she was just two years old.  Not the best mothering skills but Anne sure was a fascinating character.  She was pretty, intelligent, witty, and determined to have her own child sit on the throne of England.  She almost pulled it off, too, as Queen for four years but then something happened at the execution to prevent that.  There are a lot of theories as to what happened to poor Anne but the story is an interesting one.

3.  Queen Katherine of Aragon

She was the first wife of Henry VIII, which made for a lot of problems in the end.  She was from a foreign land, the daughter of Ferdinand and Isabella, the monarchs who "reconquered" Spain.  It was a love match at the beginning, but it didn't work out.  There are theories that Katherine actually faked the pregnancy

        moon’s dark,
        a lighted plane passes.

      2. My favorite is this, by Issa (the third verse, which I’m going to translate as:)

        The day the moon appears,
        even if it’s late, even if
        it’s cold, I feel lucky.

    1. I’ve only been to Canada once, during college, at which time I was an exchange student in Toronto. I was born in the Northeast and lived in the Pacific Northwest in high school, and then moved to Seattle in 2004. I’ve driven up to Vancouver, BC, but never actually made it into Canada.

  2. You live and grow up in a cold place
    where the dark seems to never end.
    Your only friend is the moon in the sky.

    You grow up to be a man like many
    who’ve never left the land of their birth
    but wonder about those distant lands.

    You read and travel with your mind.
    To you, they seem closer than here
    though in reality they’re far from you.

    You think of the man on the moon
    and wonder if you’ll ever join him.
    There, you can look down on your lands.

Haiku is a short Japanese poetry form consisting of three lines. The first and last lines have five syllables each and the middle line has seven. Write a haiku: 

When you write a haiku, you should follow this format: 

5 syllables, 

7 syllables, 

5 syllables. 

Your haiku must be about something in nature. 

Your haiku must have a title. 

You must draw a picture of the haiku. 


A poem can be a great way for your students to express their feelings! 

You can download the template here


This Week in Science

This week I went to my class and explained to the students what we’re going to do. 

We started talking about my class and then about science, and I’ve seen that they don’t like studying math. 

I know that they don’t like doing science at school, and that it is boring for them. 

I have an idea about how they will like to study science: playing with them.

What I’m doing with my students is asking the kids to help me collect stuff in nature.

For example, I went with them to a forest and I asked them to search for an animal and a plant in the forest. 

In the next day they went to collect leaves and flowers that they found, and I asked them to bring 15 leaves or more (or flowers). 

When they brought the leaves or the flowers, we started to talk about the plants. I asked them to bring me the parts of the plants and the color of the plant. 

When they brought me the parts of the plants, we started to learn about botany. I showed them the names of the parts. 

We had a discussion and we talked about the function of these parts. 

We made a tree with leaves and flowers. 

We talked about the differences between plants and animals. They told me that the animals have a mouth, eyes, and ears. 

When I asked them why the plants don’t have these parts, they thought that the plants can live without these parts. I explained to them that they can’t do that because they don’t have the brain to think and to move. 

After that, we did a very interesting game with them. 

I cut the leaves of the plants and the animals into pieces. 

We made a circle. The kids were sitting around the circle, and I asked them to close their eyes.

I put one of the parts of the plants or the animal in each one’s hand

Write a haiku: the sky so bright and blue
but the sun is not out there for you
the sky is crying
sadness inside but not my eyes
there will be no sunshine

A haiku is a Japanese style poem that consists of three lines. The lines are made of five syllables, seven syllables, and five syllables, respectively. The haiku should present the reader with a clear picture or snapshot of a moment. The haiku should be based on an actual experience or be about an actual experience. The haiku should present an image of one season, for example, the fall season. This could be done by writing about something that happens in that season that is associated with the season, such as the leaves changing color.

Write a haiku: rain
A haiku about rain

To be a poet is a lonely thing
A poet is alone most of the time
Poets are lonely but can write about being alone
So it can be fun being a poet

There is a tree outside my window
And it is covered in leaves
One of the leaves are blowing away
Leaving the rest of the leaves on the tree

I was on the playground today
I was playing with my brother
He threw the ball at me
And hit my nose

Yesterday when I was asleep
I had a dream that I was in my backyard
There was a huge water slide
And I slid down it for an hour

At night I look out my window
And I can hear the rain drop on the roof
It is really hard to sleep
When it is raining

The snow is getting higher and higher
And I want to see how high the snow will get
I think it will get 10 feet high
So I will probably stay inside

When you look at the night sky
And see the stars
It makes me feel really small
Because I am really small

The day is almost over
And the sun is setting
And it is really pretty
And it makes me think about tomorrow

I am walking outside
And I pass a tree
The leaves are orange and red
And they look really pretty

There is a cloud in the sky
And it has a smile on it
The clouds make shapes
And I love to look at them

It is snowing and it looks really pretty
The snow is not sticking though
It looks really pretty outside
I am going to go outside and play

I am in the park right now
And there are a lot of birds here
They are making sounds and flying around
It is really pretty

I am walking on the sidewalk
And I see a lady
I say hello to the lady
She smiles at me

I am in a big room right now
There are a lot of people in the room
The people are talking
And I am not talking

My cat sleeps on my bed
My cat is dreaming right now
He has a lot of dreams
He is dreaming about eating his food

I am outside
I am looking at the sunset
It looks really pretty right now
I am waiting for it to get darker

There is a park near my house
I am at the park right now

Write a haiku: a

Sample response: a

A haiku is a form of poem that is meant to be enjoyed by those with a good sense of humor. This particular form of poetry is easy to read and write because it is so simple. It only consists of three lines with no rhyme scheme.

The first line of this poem introduces the title. It describes what kind of person I am based on my current situation.

The second line goes on to describe something about myself that is not so pleasant. It reveals that I have not been getting enough sleep lately due to all the work I’ve been putting in at the office.

The third and final line describes something humorous or ironic happening at the office, which causes me to laugh and feel better after reading it.

Haikus are funny, but they’re also serious. They’re meant to be enjoyed by people with a sense of humor. They’re also meant to bring you some relief from all the hard work you put into life and career. This is why they’re so effective in making you laugh and smile when things get tough and make you want to cry when life gets really hard.

A good example of a haiku is A Good Poem Should Make You Laugh. This poem consists of three lines with no rhyme scheme but it does have an underlying theme that is funny if you’re able to appreciate it.

This is just one example of what a good haiku should be like. It should have a simple structure and an underlying message. It should be easy to read and write because it only consists of three lines without any rhyme scheme.

Write a haiku: I love haiku because it's a fun challenge to try to find the right words for the right syllables without going over. I'm looking forward to some great submissions. Please feel free to join in the fun and read what others have submitted.

I want to post about something that I don't understand. What it is doesn't matter. It could be quantum physics, or it could be something more mundane. The important part is that this is something I don't understand. And why don't I understand it? Because I haven't spent the necessary time studying it.

Now you might say, "How can you write about something if you don't understand it?" And I say, "Who says I need to understand it?" We often approach life the opposite way. We have the idea that we need to understand it first, so we can do it.

But I think the right way to go is to start doing, and we may eventually come to understand it better. We learn not just from books, but also from life experience.

If there's something you want to do, but you don't understand it yet, try it anyway. You may still be lost, but with each attempt, you may get a little closer to understanding. In the meantime, you're actually doing what it is you're wanting to do, and this in itself is an important lesson.


Tuesday, November 10, 2009

In praise of the coffee maker

I've been thinking about coffee makers a lot recently. Maybe this is because it's that time of year when the temperature starts to drop and our fingers are chilled and we crave something warm to drink. So here is a list of reasons why we should all be thankful for the coffee maker.

1. Hot chocolate, tea, and other beverages can also be made with it. So it's not limited to coffee!

2. It saves you the trouble of having to make coffee one cup at a time. No more running back and forth, and no need for individual coffee pots.

3. The coffee maker is usually a low cost appliance (unlike some other appliances out there that are a big expense). It's something that everyone can easily afford.

4. It saves you from spilling coffee all over the place.

5. The variety of flavors available are quite large. We can get different kinds of coffees and different blends. This is especially important for those who aren't just limited to coffee, but who enjoy tea, hot

Write a haiku: a haiku is a very specific form of poetry that has just three lines, that follow the structure 5 syllables, 7 syllables, 5 syllables. A good example would be:

A Haiku for my dog

Droopy ears and lolling tongue

Pants around my feet.


The rules for the haiku are very specific. The three lines represent one thought or image. They should have the following form:

line one: 5 syllables

line two: 7 syllables

line three: 5 syllables


There are four main elements of haiku:


1. Use of concrete imagery and description to set the scene and allow the reader to imagine and engage in the experience.

2. Use of strong verbs to convey action and emotion.

3. Use of kigo (seasonal imagery) to create a seasonal setting or mood.

4. Use of a cutting word or kireji, which may be implied rather than explicit. This cutting word is often used for a punctuation device.

So, in other words you should use descriptive language in your haiku to allow the reader to imagine the images. The lines should have a sense of emotion or feeling about them. Kigo is the seasonal aspect of the haiku. This is the most difficult aspect to achieve, however, one of the ways you can do this is by using descriptive words that have a seasonal connotation. Lastly, a cutting word is what brings the haiku to life, and is the ‘punch’ at the end.

Incorporating these elements into your poem will bring it to life and you will have written your first haiku. Don’t be scared, it is very do-able.

Haiku has been written about the most basic things in nature and it can be as simple as a line of grass, or a fallen leaf.


Here are some examples of haiku poetry:

Summer is over

Autumn is blowing in

Leaves are changing


The full moon’s glow

Gives an eerie light

Icy wind chills


Sitting on a bench

The sun sets in the west

Quiet reigns in nature


Sunrise’s colours

Paint a picture on the sky

A new day has begun


Sunset’s gold and pink

Orange rays filter through leaves

Gives a sense of calm


Sunrise’s colour

Paints the sky with colour

The days have started


Winter is here

Snowflakes

by diane lind on 8/18/2009


A haiku is a short Japanese poem that was created in the 17th century by a poet named Matsuo Basho. The haiku is a popular form of poetry in English-speaking countries. Haiku poems generally have 17 syllables with three lines, which follow this pattern:

  • the first and third lines have five syllables
  • the second line has seven syllables

The haiku poem describes something that has happened, which is usually related to nature or the seasons. The haiku is supposed to describe the situation or experience using as few words as possible.

Most of these short poems are written in the present tense and the haiku poet uses the present tense to describe the scene in as vivid a way as possible.

Here are some examples of haiku poems:

  • Summer sunlight
    streams through my window
    onto my book
  • Early Spring
    the sun shines
    on tiny green leaves
  • Autumn breeze
    rustles the dry leaves
    on the ground
  • Falling snow
    the snowflakes falling
    become a snowman

  • sonnets are a type of poem that has fourteen lines with a specific rhyme scheme. this means that every other line rhymes.
  • the rhyme scheme for a sonnet is abab cdcd efef gg. this means that the first and third lines rhyme, the second and fourth lines rhyme, the sixth and eighth lines rhyme, the seventh and ninth lines rhyme, and the tenth and thirteenth lines rhyme.

What happens in your story? Who are the characters? What do they do? What are their goals? How do they feel about each other?

Explain how you would help someone who is depressed or sad. What would you say to the person? What would you do for the person? How would you feel after helping the person?

Write about an important person in your life, such as a teacher or friend. Describe the person and explain why he or she is important to you. Describe the person’s personality, appearance, and character.

Write about an important place in your life, such as a house or a park. Describe the place and explain why it is important to you.

Activity 2: The Good Life

The World in 100 Words
In 1820, the British writer Samuel Taylor Coleridge published an essay called “A Lay Sermon on the Future of Society.” In his book, he asked and then answered the question, “Where will our next great discovery be found?” Coleridge predicted that the future would be characterized by the discoveries of explorers who travelled throughout the globe.

Coleridge’s prediction came true. During the mid-to-late 1800s, scientists discovered electricity, discovered how to extract oil from coal, invented the light bulb and created the typewriter. In the early 1900s, the automobile, the telephone, the aeroplane and the movie camera were invented.

In the first two-thirds of this century, the world was changed again by scientists. The discovery of radioactive materials led to the invention of nuclear power. Astronomers were able to show how the universe was formed, while other scientists showed that matter and energy are really two sides of the same coin.

The last few decades have seen the world changed dramatically again. The discovery of the structure of DNA in the 1950s led to new insights in the understanding of heredity. New technologies have enabled researchers to look into the heart of the sun and into the smallest parts of atoms.

Examples of 5 line poetry

What better way to learn how to write than by checking out some 5 line poetry examples? The poets listed below have different poetic styles, but they all use the five-line format. Enjoy!

Example of 5 line poetry by Shel Silverstein

Shel Silverstein (1930–1999) was a brilliant children’s poet and author. He wrote books that were funny, silly, serious, but always interesting and entertaining to read. Here is an example of 5-line poetry.

Where the Sidewalk Ends

There is a place
Where the sidewalk ends
And before the street begins,
And there the grass grows soft and white,
And there the sun burns crimson bright,

And there the moon-bird rests from his flight
To cool in the peppermint wind.

Example of 5 line poetry by Edgar Allan Poe

Here is an example of 5-line poetry from the poet who brought us the macabre and the supernatural. If you have never read Edgar Allan Poe, you will not regret the time and effort spent on the following short poem, The Bells.


Hear the loud alarum bells –

Brazen bells!

full_output:
Write a haiku: the sun rises and sets
every day, yet there are only twenty-four
hours in a day. what if there were more?

a day with twenty-eight hours, you say.
and the moon rises and sets every day,
but there are only twenty-four hours in a day.

but what if it's not the moon?
what if it's a planet that's rising and setting?
a planet you can't see, that rises and sets behind the moon

and the planet has two moons, and the planets is a little bit off?
what if the days are longer, but the moons are smaller?
and the stars are brighter, but there is no night?

you would have to live underground.
you would have to live off of artificial light.
you would have to live your life without ever knowing of the night sky

and the moon that rises and sets.
it would be a different world, for certain.
but you'd still have to make the best of it and live the life you're dealt.

Tuesday, October 28, 2008

Poetry Prompts

I like prompts. If I don't have a prompt I usually don't write. So, I'm going to start doing some poetry prompts.

Here are the first few.

Poetry Prompt 1

Describe your favorite meal in five stanzas (5 stanzas of 5 lines, 1 stanza of 2 lines). Write the title of each stanza above the stanza.

Poetry Prompt 2

Write one poem in the first person, the second poem in the second person, and the third poem in the third person. Write each stanza of the first person poem to equal the number of the stanza in the second person poem. Do the same for the third person poem. Do all three poems relate to each other?

Poetry Prompt 3

Take one of your old poems (any length, any form) and rewrite it without rhyme. I like to write a version of the poem before the final version, so do the same thing. If you choose to keep the original poem the way it is, write that as well.

Write a haiku: It is bright. It is big. My cat likes to sit in it.

What is your favorite holiday? Christmas is my favorite because it is the time of year we celebrate the birth of Jesus and it’s also the time when we gather with family and friends and share gifts.

What is your favorite activity to do when it snows? I enjoy sledding.

What is your favorite book? The Wind in the Willows (G. B. Martin) is my favorite book.

What is your favorite thing about yourself? My favorite thing about myself is my sense of humor.

What superpower would you like to have? Super-strength because it would help me carry the groceries in from the car. 

Who in your family do you admire most and why? I admire my great-grandfather because I don’t believe the story of the gold-plated coin that he lost that was once valued at about $50.  It’s a story about a lesson in generosity.  He taught my grandfather, his son, the importance of giving.


What is the weirdest dream you’ve ever had? In a dream, I was having a conversation with my father. He had passed away about 15 years earlier and, in this dream, I could still hear his voice, but I couldn’t see his face. In the dream, I realized I wanted to ask him for something, but in the dream, I couldn’t find a way to ask.  That’s when I woke up.

If you could take the class one time again, what would you do differently this time? I would make sure to pay attention and listen to what teachers were saying.

What would you like to tell a future 8th grade class at BCT? Get involved, go to lunch, play with friends, be yourself, take risks, be true to yourself, have compassion for those who are suffering, enjoy your time at school, don’t worry about the future, do your best, ask for help when you need it.

Write a haiku: Haiku is a Japanese style of poetry. It is usually composed of three lines. The first line has five syllables, the second line has seven, and the third has five. Here's an example:

Haiku by Emily Dickinson

I heard a fly buzz when I died;
The stillness round my form
Was like the stillness in the air
Between the heath and the skyline;
And then the window failed,
And then I could not see to see—
The amorous around the world
From everywhere kept coming with it
To sit awhile and then to go

Haiku Poem about Springtime

Haiku is a Japanese form of poetry which has three lines and seventeen syllables. Here are some haiku poems about springtime:

1. Scent of flowers wafts through the air,
The sun shines bright in the sky.
Spring is here!

2. Tendrils stretch out in the warm sun,
New leaves appear on trees.
Spring has come!

3. Birds sing their songs in the morning,
Flowers bloom and children play.
Spring time fun!

4. Rain falls softly from gray skies,
Clouds drift by like ships at sea.
Spring showers!

5. Butterflies float through the air,
Dandelions bloom everywhere.
Springtime delight!

7. Flowers burst into vibrant blooms,
Roses smell sweet in the air.
Spring flowers!

What is an example of a Haiku Poem? Haiku poetry consists of three lines with five syllables in the first line, seven syllables in the second line, and five syllables in the third line. Here is a haiku poem about nature:

The sun shines bright
In the azure blue sky,
The birds are singing.

This is just one example of what you can write in a haiku poem. You could also write about your emotions, or anything else that comes to mind. It is important to keep each line short, so that the reader does not get bored.

Haiku poems can be about anything, but most often they are about nature. It is a good way to express your feelings and thoughts. You could even write haiku poems about yourself! For example: I am happy today because... or I am sad today because...

full_output:
Write a haiku: 

We all love to eat ice cream! 
And I love you, my little boy! 
Today we went to eat ice cream. 
This year we will eat ice cream! 
When I will have a job, I will eat ice cream! 
Our favorite day of the week is Friday! 
When we will live together we will eat ice cream!
In the meantime we will have to wait until Friday. 
Thank you for making my day today with ice cream and our wonderful chat!

Do you know why do we need to write Haikus? We need to write them because they are one of the easiest type of poetry we can write. We need to read many books, we need to read many haikus before we can write them, it takes practice and a lot of patience.
If I had to describe a Haiku in one sentence it would be like this: A short poem describing in nature.
Before we start writing I would like to tell you some of the most important rules about haikus:
A haiku doesn't have to be 17 syllables, 3 verses or describe nature or anything! It could be anything you like, the only thing is it has to be short. It is not a haiku if it is more than 17 syllables or if it has 4 verses. If you use 4 verses it is not a haiku it is a tawakai. Another important rule for a haiku is that the 3 verses have to be a different size. If you have 5 syllables in your first verse you have to have a different amount in the second and third verses.

Here are some haiku I wrote, they are not very good but I still like them, they are written about ice cream and I want you to try to find the rules about the haikus I wrote.
I was so happy this day

I had a great time

we played together

and ate ice cream

I love ice cream 

it is my favourite thing

and I will never get tired

of eating it

I like to eat ice cream

but I don't like to get ice cream

on my nose

I would like

to go to the pool

and eat ice cream

I will wait

and eat ice cream

and then

we will go to school

I can't wait 

and tomorrow

we will eat ice cream

No comments:

Write a haiku: there was a frog
it hopped away
Author: Kavya M
1. What is a haiku?

A haiku is a type of poem, and it is from Japan. To write a haiku, you usually have to use something called a syllable. A syllable is a sound you make when you talk. The poem is written in three lines, and it tells about an image or something you see in nature.

2. Describe a haiku

Haikus are three lines long. They are also five syllables, seven syllables, and five syllables, from left to right. There are also two important words in a haiku. A word is when a person reads the haiku and makes it seem very beautiful.

3. Describe an example

Here is an example of a haiku: there was a frog he was slimy he hopped away. The three lines in the haiku are this: there was a frog, he was slimy, and he hopped away.

There are many kinds of haikus. Many people like them. Now I have learned about a type of poem.

How did you like the story? Leave a comment or write to us.

1. Why does the author like writing haikus?

a. Haikus tell about nature

b. He has no friends

c. They are easy to write

2. Why would you like to write haikus?

a. I wouldn't

b. I would because it is easy to write

c. I would because they are funny

3. What did you like best about haikus?

a. The syllables

b. The first line of the haikus

c. The poems in the haikus


1. (a) Haikus tell about nature

2. (b) I would because it is easy to write

3. (c) The poems in the haikus

full_output:
Write a haiku: 

In a haiku, a poem only has three lines. The first line contains five syllables. The second line contains seven syllables, and the last line contains five syllables. Haiku are about nature, but they don’t have to be. 


The Haiku Form in Detail

While the haiku form is short, it can be very sweet. In fact, the haiku is the second most famous type of Japanese poetry after the tanka. Despite its short length, the haiku can contain a great deal of meaning. As was mentioned, haiku poems are often about nature, although that’s not always the case. 

Haiku can take place anywhere at any time. They do not have to be in a particular setting and it’s not necessary to have a rhyme or a set rhythm. Traditionally, Japanese haiku are written in one line, but most English haiku are written with three lines. 


Haiku Examples 


On the Beach

By Dōgo Ariki 

I am waiting,
the evening wind blows away
my last dream

This simple haiku by Dōgo Ariki is an interesting one. The title gives one idea, but the first line changes it all. The speaker is sitting in the sand, possibly just having finished an evening meal. The speaker is alone and sad, perhaps with only memories to keep them company. These memories will now be blown away by the wind. 

The reader can see in this instance how brevity and simplicity work together in the haiku form. In just 13 words, this poet has painted a picture of solitude and loss. The reader’s mind will fill in the gaps and bring this haiku to life. 


The Last Snowman 

By J. Bruehl 

The last snowman 
waits for a new season 
and an end to spring

The last snowman 

This is another example of haiku that makes use of a clever juxtaposition. The reader can visualize a snowman. They are likely thinking about one they saw as a child or made themselves. He is standing there waiting for a new season and an end to spring. As the reader fills in the gaps, they’re likely considering the fact that winter will soon end and so will the snowman. 


What is a Japanese haiku?

A Japanese haiku is a poem that was written in Japan during the early seventeenth century

The haiku must be romantic, sensual or sexual. Avoid writing poems that are depressing, philosophical, mean-spirited, dull, political, or completely abstract.
A haiku is a Japanese verse form consisting of three lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables, respectively. A haiku should capture a single moment with clarity and conciseness.
What is a poem?

Here's a poem that I wrote:
If I were a flower,
I would grow in your field,
to bloom in summer.


Write a limerick: there was a man named gus, he was very bad tempered and always said the rudest things
A limerick is a five-line poem of rhyming verse that's usually humorous. Limericks contain an AABBA rhyme scheme. The first, second, and fifth lines are longer than the third and fourth lines.

Here's a limerick:
A big boy was sitting on a stool
He found out that birds fly in a pool
He ate a small frog
And when he was a log
And he grew into the biggest fool.

What is poetry?

Here's a poem that I wrote:
The poet looks at the blank page,
And smiles, at the white space of his cage.
He writes in prose,
Because nobody knows
That poetry and truth are one and the same face.

A poem is a verbal expression of one's feelings. Poems have a rhythm and pattern. The rhyme scheme can be used, or not, but poets usually use repetition. The poet uses the right words that create a picture, mood, or emotion.

What is a sonnet?

Here's a sonnet that I wrote:
I see your love through your eyes
and I know it's there
for as far as my sight is,
your love is in the air
You smile, I feel joy
You speak, I'm all ears
You touch, I feel your embrace
All your tender tears

A sonnet is a poem containing 14 lines. The 14 lines are usually written in iambic pentameter. The first 8 lines are called the octave and the last 6 lines are called the sestet.

There are two main kinds of sonnets: the Italian sonnet, also called the Petrachan sonnet, and the English sonnet, also called the Shakespearean sonnet.

an image, preferably nature.

A Haiku is a very short Japanese poem. It is written in the classical form, and is three lines of 5, 7 and 5 syllables. (Remember, if you’re not writing in Japanese, you’re already diverging from the traditional Haiku.) It’s not all about syllables, though, it’s about the emotion behind the words and lines. The third line should make a shift and add something to the poem – as though it’s an extra dimension. Here are a few examples:

Old pond

A frog jumps in

The sound of water

–Matsuo Basho (1644 – 1694)

I am an onion

I live in the kitchen

You may weep when

you peel me

–Wera Ebelin


A few more examples of haiku for inspiration:

Dew drops, so fine

When rain wears the flowers

They twinkle, in the

aftermath of the
fallen drops of the sun
–Hoshan Yamaguchi


Here is my haiku:

Mossy branches

Birds chirp their melodies

A gentle lullaby

How about yours?



How to write a Poem

Poetry writing is a special skill. It is also one that can be picked up easily if you have the desire to express yourself in this way. Let me show you what I mean… Below is an activity you can do to get you started. It’s a poem that’s called a “found poem”. The word “found” comes from the idea that the words are found in a newspaper or from an everyday message or a poem already in existence. You’ll be amazed at what poems you can “find” in a newspaper!

Step 1: Find an ad or article in the newspaper.

Step 2: Choose two or three words from the ad.

Step 3: Rearrange them, but don’t change the words.

Step 4: Read over the words. See if you can make the words into a poem. If you can’t, try it again on another ad.

And here are the rules:

1. No changing of words!

2. The more words you use, the better.

3. The more words you use, the more ideas you will find.

Here’s my found poem:

Shining like the sun

the

full_output:
Write a haiku: there is a lot going on in that little haiku.

But before I share another one with you, I want to tell you a little bit about what haiku are, and what their history is.

The haiku form was actually developed in Japan and you can read more about the history of the haiku here. But what the Japanese haiku poets wrote, were poems of 5-7-5 syllables (versus a lot of words).

These three lines of poetry are broken into phrases, the first two containing five syllables each, the last a seven-syllable. The lines must not be simply the count of a single word repeated thrice, but the composition of two or three phrases each in three lines of 5, 7 and 5 syllables. A haiku usually has a seasonal word in it and also a metaphorical or literary effect.

I’ve always liked haiku. As a kid, I would love to try my hand at them. But I never really thought that I was very good at them. The thing about haiku is that most kids have no idea that it is supposed to be a metaphorical type of poem. You’re not supposed to use the same word three times. You’re not supposed to have three lines that are the same. There’s so much more to a haiku than just making it 5-7-5.

But, as an adult, I was introduced to haiku, again. And I thought that I would try my hand at it. And this time, I tried to think about what would make a haiku a good one.

And what I learned, is this:

The first line of a haiku is what sets up the poem. It often uses a single word.

The second line is a continuation of the first line. It often sets up the metaphor of the poem.

The third line is the conclusion.

When I realized this, I finally saw that I could be pretty good at a haiku, if I wanted to. I had been doing it all along, without realizing it. And that’s why I’m going to share some of my haikus with you.


The first, is about… well, what do you think it’s about?


And here’s another:


I hope you liked it.

And, if you’re feeling the haiku love, I encourage you to give it a try. You might find that you like it too!

Write a haiku: Haiku is very short poem, it's very old form of writing. But it's very easy to write. Haiku have 5 syllables for first and last lines and 7 syllables for 2nd line.

What's the difference between poetry and prose?

Poetry is short and descriptive, written with a lot of rhythm, and often has rhyming words at the end of each line. Prose is longer and tells a story, it isn't as descriptive as poetry. Prose doesn't have to rhyme.

What is the use of meter in poetry?

Meter is the rhythmic pattern established by the syllables in a line of poetry. It's the arrangement of stressed and unstressed syllables. In English poetry, meter is based upon the use of feet, which are combinations of syllables in a certain arrangement. The syllables within a foot determine whether it is a weak or strong stress

Which of the following best describes the difference between a sonnet and a ballad?

Ballads tell of a great event, a sonnet is a 14 line poem with a specific rhyming scheme. You could say that a ballad is like a long sonnet.

What is the difference between Shakespeare and Dante's sonnets?

The main difference between them is the language in which the sonnets are written. Since Shakespeare was writing in English (Shakespearean Sonnet) while Dante was writing in Italian (Italian Sonnet).

What is poetry and prose and what is the difference between poetry and prose?

Prose is spoken or written word that is not in verse, or meter, but rather is organized according to normal syntax and grammar. Poetry is similar to prose but is written in lines and, typically, has a meter.

What is the difference between a limerick and a sonnet?

Both a sonnet and a limerick are types of poetry. The main difference between the two is the number of lines each contains. A sonnet has fourteen lines while a limerick contains five or more lines. Another difference is that a sonnet is written in iambic pentameter but a limerick is not.

Penguin Writing!

Hi! Today I am doing a writing activity with penguins! It is really easy and fun! Just follow these steps…

Step One: Draw a penguin.

Ex: A chubby penguin in front of a white background. Use black to draw its eyes, flippers, and feet. Use blue to draw its belly button and its mouth. Draw a white tummy and use blue and yellow to make the patterns for its tummy.

Step Two: Draw a penguin habitat! (a place where the penguin lives)

Ex: Use black and orange to draw some grass, and make some hills. Use orange to draw an ocean. Then use blue to draw the sky, clouds, and waves. Finally use blue to draw some stars.

Monday, July 3, 2017

Writing Advice: Why Editors Are Important

I often hear writers complain about how bad editors are, how they don’t care about authors, and how they aren’t helpful at all. I hear how so-and-so editor got my manuscript wrong, the only thing they got right was the genre, and they’re basically out to ruin my career.

There’s an article about editors I read a while ago, and I completely forgot about it until this week. It’s a good, eye-opening article that explains why editors are so important and what happens when writers try to go it alone. You can read the article here, if you’re interested.

When I started editing, I learned a lot about the importance of an editor. I realized how difficult it is to edit a story, and how much work goes into it. I’ve seen some of the mistakes editors make in the books I read, and while those mistakes might seem annoying, they’re usually easy to spot. I also understand why editors can be so strict when working with other writers. They’re trying to protect you, after all.

What do you think about editors? Would you rather work with an editor, or do you prefer to go it alone?

Reading Response #4

We just read a great book named 'No Boys Allowed'. It was about three kids who decided to have a sleepover because they were so sad that they didn't have a special friend. When they had a sleepover, they had so much fun but when they woke up in the morning their friend wasn't at the house. They finally found out he left a map and wrote a note explaining that he was sorry for not writing back. He also wrote that he was going to visit his grandma and to ask his dad for permission to see him tomorrow. The next day he went to the store to see his friend with the help of the other friends. The kids at the store ended up making an extra ticket for his dad. He came and they got to ride their bikes home. It was a happy ending. I liked this book and gave it five stars. It was funny and it had a great ending. I really thought it was so interesting and it made me happy.

full_output:
Write a haiku: haiku

A haiku is a very brief 3-line poem usually about nature. The first and third lines are five syllables in length, and the second is seven. The form has been popular for centuries. When you write your haiku, take care to choose very precise language.

Write a limerick: limerick

A limerick is a humorous 5-line poem. This short form of poetry has a strict rhyme scheme, so read lots of samples to get a sense of the rhythm before you try to write your own. You can start a limerick with a word such as “Here we go,” “Once there was,” or “There was a girl who” to get your ideas flowing.

Write a tanka: tanka

This ancient 5-line poem from Japan was especially popular during the Edo period. The first and third lines are five syllables in length and the second, fourth, and fifth lines are seven syllables each. Read many tanka before you try to write one.

Write a list poem: list poem

Write a poem that’s composed entirely of a list of items, like the things you did on your summer vacation, or the reasons you love someone.

Write a found poem: found poem

A found poem is based on a larger body of text you find interesting. A found poem is a good way to practice the art of editing. You can find poems in novels, magazines, signs, even song lyrics. When you find a piece that strikes you, try to isolate the words and phrases you find most interesting. The words you choose will naturally be influenced by your style, and you can also add a few lines of your own.

A haiku is a very brief 3-line poem usually about nature. The first and third lines are five syllables in length, and the second is seven. The form has been popular for centuries. When you write your haiku, take care to choose very precise language.

Write a limerick: limerick

A limerick is a humorous 5-line poem. This short form of poetry has a strict rhyme scheme, so read lots of samples to get a sense of the rhythm before you try to write your own. You can start a limerick with a word such as “Here we go,” “Once there was,” or “There was a girl who” to get your ideas flowing.

Write a tanka: tanka

This ancient 5-line poem from Japan was especially popular during the Edo period. The first and third lines are five syllables in length and the second, fourth, and fifth lines are seven syllables each. Read many tanka before you try to write one.

Write a list poem: list poem

Write a poem that’s composed entirely of a list of items, like the things you did on your summer vacation, or the reasons you love someone.

Write a found poem: found poem

A found poem is based on a larger body of text you find interesting. A found poem is a good way to practice the art of editing. You can find poems in novels, magazines, signs, even song lyrics. When you find a piece that strikes you, try to isolate the words and phrases you find most interesting. The words you choose will naturally be influenced by your style, and you can also add a few lines of your own.

What is the opposite of a metaphor? The opposite of a metaphor would be literal language. 


What is the opposite of a hyperbole? The opposite of a hyperbole would be a literal statement.


What is the opposite of a metonymy? The opposite of a metonymy would be an analogy.


What is the opposite of synecdoche? The opposite of synecdoche would be a simile or an analogy. 



What is the opposite of apostrophe? The opposite of an apostrophe would be a declarative statement. Or any other sentence form that does not call to someone that is not there. 


What is the opposite of oxymoron? The opposite of an oxymoron would be a literal statement. 


What is the opposite of assonance? The opposite of assonance would be alliteration.


What is the opposite of sibilance? The opposite of sibilance would be the sound of a cat’s purr. This one is a tough one.

The opposite of assonance is alliteration.
The opposite of sibilance is cat purring.
The opposite of the oxymoron is a literal statement.

full_output:
Write a haiku: haiku

Sitting here writing,
My cat just rolled over.
He is such a cutie.

The above haiku was just a few minutes of free form writing. In my experience, it is always best to free form write first. Then, if necessary, edit. If you are having a hard time getting started, here are some questions that I used to find a topic.

  • What are you doing right now?
  • What was the funniest thing that happened to you yesterday?
  • What is your favorite color? Why is it your favorite?
  • What was your worst (or most embarrassing) moment?
  • What is your favorite food? How would you describe your favorite food? Is it sweet, sour, salty, spicy or what?
  • What’s something you’ve always wanted?
  • If you had three wishes, what would you ask for? Be careful what you wish for!

Have fun writing. Enjoy!

P.S. Don’t forget to practice your writing everyday!

Leave a Reply

Write a haiku: Haiku is a very particular and short Japanese poem style, that contains three lines: the first and the last lines have five syllables, and the second line has seven syllables. It is used to express deep feelings about the surrounding world or nature. An example of such poetry could look like this:

Sunshine dances
On the waves, on the wind, on
The dew on the grass. (6)

Write a cinquain: This type of poem has five lines as well, and expresses the theme of the poem in a metaphorical way, so its lines are connected. It starts with a noun, the second line consists of two adjectives, the third line has three verbs, the fourth line consists of four nouns, and the fifth line is a synonym of the first word:

Firefighters brave
Sting of smoke and heat, douse flames
To save lives and home. (7)

Write a limerick: This type of poetry, that comes from England, is known for its humor and catchy rhythm. It is usually a funny poem made of 5 lines, where every line has 9-10 syllables. To write a good limerick, you have to understand its peculiar rhythm and structure, and the most important is that you shouldn’t mention anything offensive, as it can be against the law in some places. Here is an example of a short limerick:

A young man called Sam
Once took a walk to the farm.
On his way to the barn
He was bitten by a ram.
You see, Sam's family was warm. (8)

Write a haiga: This form of poetry originates from Japan, and consists of a short tanka poem, that has five lines of 5, 7, 5, 7, 7 syllables respectively, and an image to depict it. Tanka poem talks about the surroundings, while the image depicts the situation described in the poem. There is not much to write about haiga, the most important thing is the connection of the poem to the drawing. If the poem is about the autumn, then the picture should depict the leaves on the trees, and so on. Here is an example of a short haiga:

The snow comes down
White as the clouds, cold, silent
I think of you here
In a warm cozy bed
And a cup of hot tea. (9)

It starts with a noun, the second line consists of two adjectives, the third line has three verbs, the fourth line consists of four nouns, and the fifth line is a synonym of the first word:

Firefighters brave
Sting of smoke and heat, douse flames
To save lives and home. (7)

Write a limerick: This type of poetry, that comes from England, is known for its humor and catchy rhythm. It is usually a funny poem made of 5 lines, where every line has 9-10 syllables. To write a good limerick, you have to understand its peculiar rhythm and structure, and the most important is that you shouldn’t mention anything offensive, as it can be against the law in some places. Here is an example of a short limerick:

A young man called Sam
Once took a walk to the farm.
On his way to the barn
He was bitten by a ram.
You see, Sam's family was warm. (8)

Write a haiga: This form of poetry originates from Japan, and consists of a short tanka poem, that has five lines of 5, 7, 5, 7, 7 syllables respectively, and an image to depict it. Tanka poem talks about the surroundings, while the image depicts the situation described in the poem. There is not much to write about haiga, the most important thing is the connection of the poem to the drawing. If the poem is about the autumn, then the picture should depict the leaves on the trees, and so on. Here is an example of a short haiga:

The snow comes down
White as the clouds, cold, silent
I think of you here
In a warm cozy bed
And a cup of hot tea. (9)

Write a haiku: It will help you express your feelings in a simple but effective way.

Read a book to someone. Find a book at your local library or on your own shelf, and read to a parent, sibling, or another person who needs a break and a good laugh.

Say thank you. When you say thank you to someone, you make them feel good. Your kind words can help them have a happier day.

Share your good mood. Help make someone else feel good by telling them you appreciate something that they did. Maybe your little sister made her bed without being asked, or your brother kept his hands to himself while you were playing a game with him. Telling them you noticed these things will make them feel even better.

For more tips, see KidsHealth’s “10 Ways to Spread Joy.” You’ll have the best day if you help others have a great day too!

Reviewed by: D'Arcy Lyness, PhD
Date reviewed: February 2014

Write a haiku: 

Haiku is an ancient Japanese form of poetry, and are often based on nature or the seasons. You should write a short poem in three lines. Your first line should have five syllables. The second line should have seven syllables, and the third line should have five syllables. 

Examples of a Haiku

Haikus are a good place to start. Here are some haikus that might inspire you.

Line 1 (5 syllables):

A small, white bird sat
On the ground, as if praying. 
My feet are too wide. 

Line 2 (7 syllables):

As he opened his wings
To fly away to the clouds,
The wind blew a lot.

Line 3 (5 syllables): 

I was on the bus
There was a girl sitting next to me
It was nice to talk to her.

2. Write a Haiku using your favorite color

Haiku is a Japanese short-form poetry that consists of three short lines. Haiku is characterized by a short, simple, and complete image. Haiku has five syllables in the first line, seven syllables in the second, and five syllables in the third. You can find the best Haiku by using your favorite color. Here are some tips to writing a Haiku using your favorite color:

  1. Think about what your favorite color is. Is it blue, green, or purple? Once you have identified your favorite color, write down what you like about that color.
  2. Now, let’s write a Haiku using your favorite color. Your first line should include a description of your favorite color. For example, “Blue is my favorite color.”

    Your second line should describe how you feel when you think about that color. For example, “Blue makes me feel happy.”

    Your third line should describe something that you like or dislike about that color. For example, “I like the way blue looks on me.”

3. Write a Haiku using nature

A Haiku is a short poem that usually contains three lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables. A Haiku can be about anything, but it’s often about nature. You can write a Haiku about nature by looking around you and finding something interesting to describe. 

Some ideas include:

  • A tree
  • A flower
  • A bird
  • A sunset
